title: Comment from Anonymous
comment:
As explained in the attached comment, I am one of the 50,000 federal employees who will be affected by this initiative and strongly oppose it.



--- ATTACHMENTS ---

[ATTACHMENT: Comment for OPM]
April 23, 2025 Office of Personnel Management 1900 E Street NW Washington, DC 20415-1000 Re: RIN 3206-AO80, “Improving Performance, Accountability and Responsiveness in the Civil Service” Dear OPM, I am a career regulatory analyst in the “Office of Policy” of a federal agency with over 10 years of experience in my current position. As one of the 50,000 federal employees who could lose my job as a consequence of Schedule Policy/Career, I strongly oppose this rulemaking. Despite OPM’s assurances to the contrary, I fear that officials in the current administration, or in a future administration, will exploit Schedule Policy/Career to facilitate “mass head-count reductions in the federal bureaucracy.” 1Given my experience, I am under no illusions that anything I say will persuade OPM to abandon its implementation of amended Executive Order 13957 and Schedule Policy/Career. Indeed, OPM has telegraphed that a reversal isn’t happening, asserting that it “must comport with” Executive Order 13957 and that “[d]eclining to help the President execute this directive would be a dereliction of OPM’s statutory duty.” Fair enough; it would be unrealistic to expect OPM to 2second-guess an executive order issued by the current President. Accordingly, feds like me will pin our hopes on the judicial branch, which will independently assess whether the Trump administration’s novel reinterpretation of the Civil Service Reform Act of 1978 is the “best reading” of that statute under Loper Bright Enterprises v. Raimondo, 144 S. Ct. 2244, 2266 (2024). 3While the outcome of this rulemaking may be preordained, I have written this comment for one important purpose. Taking advantage of the candor afforded by anonymity, I hope to refute the disparaging suspicion of federal employees at the heart of Executive Order 14171—not only to underscore that this initiative is unnecessary, but to convey to Trump administration officials that  Elon Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy, The DOGE Plan to Reform Government, Wall Street Journal (Nov. 120, 2024), https://www.wsj.com/opinion/musk-and-ramaswamy-the-doge-plan-to-reform-government-supreme-court-guidance-end-executive-power-grab-fa51c020https://www.wsj.com/opinion/musk-and-ramaswamy-the-doge-plan-to-reform-government-supreme-court-guidance-end-executive-power-grab-fa51c020. 90 FR 17200, 17218.2 As a regulatory analyst, it would be supremely ironic if the Loper Bright decision ends up saving my 3job. 1
they can trust in the capability and professionalism of career policy staff. Whether you believe it or not, we are here to help you.  However, trust is a two-way street, and OPM has done much to diminish its credibility in the initial months of this administration. To the extent OPM is sincere in promising that “employees 4who faithfully perform their jobs to the best of their ability have little to fear from Schedule Policy/Career,” I urge OPM to implement meaningful safeguards beyond those included in its 5NPRM—in particular, language that would prohibit the arbitrary firing or mass firing of Schedule Policy/Career employees. Such safeguards would demonstrate OPM’s sincerity about the stated intent of amended Executive Order 13957—i.e., holding bad actors accountable—while mitigating some of its harms. A Solution in Search of a Problem Before getting into the details of the NPRM, I wish to share my perspective as a federal employee who will likely be reclassified into Schedule Policy/Career, retaining my anonymity for obvious reasons. For context, I previously commented in support of OPM’s 2024 rule and was quoted at length in the preamble of that rule.  6As I described in my earlier comment, I am a GS-13 regulatory analyst who works in the “Office of Policy” of a prominent federal agency. For better or worse, my agency engages in some of the most contentious policy work in the federal government. For example, my agency’s policy priorities change dramatically depending on the political party in charge of the Presidency. Our rulemakings typically attract thousands of comments and have been the subject of Congressional committee hearings. Adverse stakeholders challenge our rules and sub-regulatory guidance in court, with disputes occasionally reaching the U.S. Supreme Court. My “substantive participation” in this contested policy work is important and exciting, but given its sensitivity, I 7am scrupulous to maintain the effort, professionalism, and objectivity expected of a taxpayer-funded federal employee. As a career analyst, I have worked closely and successfully with political appointees under the Obama, Trump, and Biden administrations to issue regulations and policy guidance consistent with the policy priorities of those administrations. Naturally, I have personal opinions about the policy work I do, and I sometimes disagree with my politically appointed leaders about specific  See, e.g., Eric Katz, As Re-Firings Begin, Judge Demands Trump Administration Tell Probationary 4Employees They Were Not Let Go for Poor Performance, Politico (April 21, 2025), https://www.politico.com/news/2025/02/27/opm-firing-probationary-federal-agency-employees-judge-ruling-00206615; Billy Mitchell, OPM Quietly Swapped Out Privacy Assessment for Governmentwide Email System Central to Ongoing Litigation, FedScoop (March 3, 2025), https://fedscoop.com/opm-email-privacy-assessment-swap-ongoing-litigation/. 90 FR 17218. 5 See 89 FR 25001 (Comment 3195).6 E.O. 13957, sec. 5(c)(i).7 2
policies or projects. In fact, robust civil service protections have empowered me—and, collectively, my coworkers and other career employees—to occasionally share policy recommendations or serious concerns with agency leadership, which sometimes results in our leadership changing course. This is a perfectly normal and healthy process, as career civil servants are supposed to provide candid deliberative advice to the politically appointed leaders who ultimately make the decisions. As OPM continues to recognize, candid internal feedback 8from career policy staff helps to ensure that regulatory changes and other policy initiatives are maximally effective, sustainable, and legally defensible. At the same time, I and other career federal employees certainly understand that we are not the decisionmakers. Elections in a democracy have consequences, and it is entirely appropriate for agencies to pursue the policy preferences of the elected President who appoints its leaders. This is widely understood by all federal employees, who typically go above and beyond Hatch Act requirements to refrain from appearing politically biased whether we’re on or off the clock. Speaking personally, I have often worked to delay, withdraw, rescind, and/or replace rules that I helped a previous administration to promulgate. Occasionally, I have drafted preamble language rebutting the very same language that I personally authored years before in an earlier rulemaking. I have also proactively “pitched” policy ideas to agency leadership in every Presidential administration, including in this administration. In fact, I and my coworkers have already brainstormed numerous ideas for regulatory relief consistent with the deregulatory aims of Executive Orders 14192 and 14219. 9 Given this experience, I am incredulous at OPM’s assertion that policy resistance is “a widespread phenomenon.” This assertion is a reversal from OPM’s findings last year, and it 1011flies in the face of my personal experience. Sensationalist claims about a widespread “deep state” or “resistance” within the federal civil service simply do not reflect reality. For example, if there truly was widespread “policy resistance” against the Trump administration among the 50,000 employees who might be reclassified into Schedule Policy/Career, one would expect ubiquitous leaks about agency rulemakings and other sensitive policy initiatives to news outlets and adverse stakeholders. Here, OPM cites to just one example of a career employee ever leaking a policy document—a draft Presidential executive order promoting classical and traditional architectural styles in the design of federal buildings. This one example, involving a seemingly trivial policy 12issue, does not establish that policy resistance is a “widespread” phenomenon. 13 See 90 FR 17208 (“Career staff critiques, especially those coming from a political perspective that 8differs from political appointees, ultimately strengthens policymaking and produces better agency decisions.”).  See 90 FR 9065 (Executive Order 14192); 90 FR 10583 (Executive Order 14219). 9 90 FR 17194.10 89 FR 25000 (“OPM does not agree that employing civil servants … thwarts the agenda of any 11President, and [such assertions] lack any well-founded support.”). 90 FR 17193 n. 151.12 To be clear, I do not condone the actions of that apparently disgruntled architect.13 3
The truth is that, like me, the overwhelming majority of career staff respect the integrity of the policymaking process and the importance of deferring to our Presidentially-appointed leaders. OPM’s citation to unscientific poll results and a handful of clickbait articles do not make a persuasive case to the contrary. In sum, Schedule Policy/Career appears to be a solution in search of a problem. I am not opposed to holding bad actors accountable, but I have never witnessed or heard about insubordination or “policy resistance” at my agency of the kind imagined in the NPRM. So, as a threshold matter, I disagree that there is a problem serious enough to justify stripping civil service protections from me and 50,000 other federal employees. Weak Protections and Hollow Assurances Section 6 of amended Executive Order 13957 provides that “[e]mployees in or applicants for Schedule Policy/Career positions are not required to personally or politically support the current President or the policies of the current administration,” and separately instructs agencies to “establish rules to prohibit the same personnel practices prohibited by [5 U.S.C. 2302(b)] with respect to any employee or applicant for employment in Schedule Policy/Career of the excepted service.” Additionally, amended Executive Order 13957 deviates from the original Executive 14Order 13957 by designating the new schedule as “Schedule Policy/Career” rather than “Schedule F”—ostensibly to rebut “misinformation” that the administration will use the new schedule as “a means of converting career positions to political positions.” 15These protections are better than nothing, but they seem functionally unenforceable. As OPM noted last year: Once hirings and firings are at-will … [an] employee might not have an entitlement to written notice of the reasons for [an] adverse action, an opportunity to respond, or a written decision. Nor would the decision generally be appealable. It would thus be, at a minimum, difficult for employees to protect themselves from actions based on political beliefs or party allegiance because no cause (or evidence) would be required prior to such an action. Under Schedule F, because such an employee would be at-will, the employer would need to give little or no reason prior to a termination. In short, Schedule F leaves innumerable ways for politics to factor into these traditionally merit-based decisions in a manner that would be difficult to detect or remedy. 16Even in its new NPRM, OPM acknowledges the risk that “some [agency] officials” may “treat Schedule Policy/Career positions as noncareer positions” and fire employees for perceived  E.O. 13957, sec. 6.14 90 FR 17200.15 89 FR 24994 (citations omitted).16 4
political disloyalty. In response, OPM replies that it will “be heavily involved in the 17implementation of Schedule Policy/Career” and “if necessary … can recommend additional measures to prevent abuses.” Respectfully, these vague assurances are not good enough. OPM 18is the federal agency with the duty to implement amended Executive Order 13957 and should not wait for predictable harms to materialize before merely “recommend[ing]” solutions. Indeed, section 6(a) of amended Executive Order 13957 instructs that “agencies”—including OPM—“shall establish rules to prohibit [certain] personnel practices” against Schedule Policy/Career employees, but OPM’s NPRM fails to include any language about prohibited personnel 19practices in the proposed reg text for 5 CFR 213.3501. At minimum, OPM should fix that 20oversight in its final rule. Of course, the bigger problem is that nothing in OPM’s NPRM or in the express text of amended Executive Order 13957 will protect Schedule Policy/Career employees from mass firings. As OPM notes, “placing … employees into Schedule Policy/Career makes them functionally at-will.” Thus, as long as agencies do not discriminate when they fire individual employees, 21agency heads will be newly empowered to quickly fire large groups of federal employees for no reason at all—as many as 50,000 across the federal government, according to OPM's estimate in the NPRM. Contemplating the protections afforded to Schedule Policy/Career employees, one 22is reminded of Joseph Stalin’s infamous distinction between tragedies and statistics. In a tacit acknowledgement of concerns that Schedule Policy/Career could be used for mass firings, OPM assures that “employees who faithfully perform their jobs to the best of their ability have little to fear from Schedule Policy/Career … [as] agencies have strong incentives not to dismiss employees who are competently performing their assigned duties.” Of particular 23relevance to me, OPM aptly notes that “drafting regulations and guidance … are complex tasks that require considerable experience with the subject matter and technical procedures” which “[f]ew newly hired employees—career or noncareer—can do … effectively,” concluding that “a President who wants agencies to implement his policies has strong incentives not to dismiss experienced regulation writers who are performing timely and quality work, no matter their personal political affiliation.” Relatedly, OPM asserts that “the President and his appointees 24have additional incentivizes to maintain a career workforce that contains a diversity of views and opinions … [as] frank and fearless advice to agency leadership … helps agencies make better decisions, which the President and agency leaders value.” 25 90 FR 17209. 17 Id.18 E.O. 13957, sec. 6(a) (emphasis added).19 See 90 FR 17222.20 90 FR 17218.21 90 FR 17220.22 90 FR 17218.23 90 FR 17208.24 90 FR 17208-09.25 5
I wholeheartedly agree with OPM’s statements quoted in the paragraph above, but they ring hollow in light of other actions and statements from the Trump administration exhibiting extreme hostility towards federal employees, including from President Trump. For example, in 26describing his regulatory freeze order issued on January 20, 2025, President Trump deviated from prepared remarks to quip that “Most of those bureaucrats are being fired, they’re gone. Should be all of them, but some sneak through, but we have to live with a couple I guess.”  27In this context, in the absence of specific safeguards to prevent us from being fired for arbitrary reasons, OPM’s assurances to career staff in the NPRM feels like gaslighting from the villain in a predictable horror film. “I’m so happy to have you for dinner! Would you mind stepping down into that soundproof basement?” Conclusion While civil service protections are important for all federal employees, they are particularly important for career policy staff, who perform important work for considerably less pay than what they could earn in the private sector. Candor is key to our jobs, and civil service 28protections are key to our candor. Unfortunately, amended Executive Order 13957 and new Schedule Policy/Career will strip civil service protections from thousands of federal employees who are already weary and demoralized—an extremely misguided policy move. Among other harms, the new Schedule Policy/Career will: •jeopardize the careers and livelihoods of thousands of federal employees;  •deter career staff from providing candid deliberative advice for fear of perceived “resistance;” and • damage government efforts to recruit, hire, and retain talent, thereby reducing the speed and effectiveness of the federal government.  See Executive Order 14210 of February 11, 2025, 90 FR 9669 (instructing agencies to “promptly 26undertake preparations to initiate large-scale reductions in force”); see also, e.g., Molly Redden and Andy Kroll, “Put Them in Trauma”: Inside a Key MAGA Leader’ s Plans for a New Trump Agenda, ProPublica (Oct. 24, 2024), https://www.propublica.org/article/video-donald-trump-russ-vought-center-renewing-america-maga; Taylor Giorno, ‘We Are Terrified’: Musk Puts USAID Through ‘Wood Chipper,’ The Hill (Feb. 3, 2025), https://www.thehill.com/policy/technology/5122676-usaid-shutdown-elon-musk-doge/. See https://www.youtube.com/live/SzozeHjyLv4?t=656s; see also Erich Wagner, Trump: Agencies 27Should Fire 'All' Bureaucrats, Government Executive (Jan. 20, 2025), https://www.govexec.com/workforce/2025/01/trump-agencies-should-fire-all-bureaucrats/402353/. For example, according to the Congressional Budget Office, “Federal workers with a professional 28degree or doctorate—about 10 percent of the federal workforce—earn about 29 percent less, on average, than their private-sector counterparts.” Congressional Budget Office, “Comparing the Compensation of Federal and Private-Sector Employees in 2022,” (April 2024) at 1, https://www.cbo.gov/publication/60235. 6
Additional safeguards—such as a language prohibiting the arbitrary firing or mass firing of Schedule Policy/Career employees—could mitigate some of these harms, but this administration’s damage to the federal workforce has already been immense. I don’t fault other federal employees who have decided to move on, but I plan to stick around as long as I can, as I continue to believe in the mission of my agency and in the importance of my job to that mission.  Going forward, I hope to work in partnership with my agency’s new leadership, who I do not hold at fault for the actions of others in this administration. I had positive personal relationships with political appointees from the first Trump administration, and I hope that a successful collaboration this time around can serve as a positive example for the rest of the federal government. At the same time, consistent with OPM’s recommendation, I will continue to provide “frank and fearless advice to agency leadership” when I see critical mistakes. This 29comment is submitted in that spirit. Thank you for your consideration.

title: Comment from Csaba  Skultety
comment: As a United States citizen and spouse of a federal employee, I am very much opposed to this new regulation. The federal workforce has protections in place in order to keep employees from being fired whenever a new administration is elected. The proposed regulation assumes that many federal employees are lazy, incompetent, or otherwise unfit to do their jobs and therefore proposes relaxing the protections currently in place in order to remove these employees from the federal workforce. However, this presumption is false. Most federal employees are hard-working Americans who have dedicated their lives to serving the public. They work just as hard as anyone in the private sector. The regulation pretends to care about performance, accountability, and responsiveness, but completely ignores the fact that almost every single agency in the government is being downsized already and performance and responsiveness will, in fact, suffer because of those downsizing efforts. Therefore it feels like this regulation actually has very little to do with performance, accountability, and responsiveness, and more to do with replacing employees who do not voice support for the administration's policies. Replacing knowledgeable, hard working people with yes-men, will not make the government more responsive or performant.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment: As a dedicated scientist and small business owner committed to the principles of evidence-based research and the mission of the National Institutes of Health (NIH), I am deeply concerned about the proposed rule titled "Improving Performance, Accountability, and Responsiveness in the Civil Service" (FR Document: 2025-06904). While enhancing accountability within the civil service is a commendable goal, certain aspects of this proposal could inadvertently compromise the nonpartisan foundation essential to scientific endeavors and public trust.The proposal suggests reclassifying policy-influencing positions into a new "Schedule Policy/Career" category, rendering them at-will roles exempt from standard adverse action procedures and appeals. Although these positions are described as remaining career jobs filled on a nonpartisan basis, the at-will nature inherently introduces a vulnerability to political influence. This is particularly concerning for scientific agencies like the NIH, where policy decisions must be grounded in rigorous, unbiased research rather than shifting political agendas.The ability to remove employees without the usual procedural safeguards could deter scientists from pursuing innovative or controversial research topics, fearing repercussions tied to political sensitivities rather than scientific merit. Such an environment risks stifling scientific progress and undermines the credibility of institutions that rely on objective analysis to inform public health policies.To preserve the integrity of scientific research and maintain public confidence in our institutions, I urge a reconsideration of the provisions that allow for at-will employment in policy-influencing positions. Implementing robust protections against political interference is crucial to ensure that science remains a guiding force for the public good, free from partisan pressures.

title: Comment from Dave Phox
comment: I’m firmly against bringing back or creating anything like “Schedule F” for federal employees. This kind of policy would deal a serious blow to the merit-based civil service system that has kept our federal workforce professional and nonpartisan for well over 100 years.Let’s be clear—this idea goes completely against the spirit of the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883. That law was passed to stop the old “spoils system,” where jobs were handed out as political favors, and instead establish a system based on merit. Schedule F would do the opposite—it would allow large numbers of career civil servants, especially those involved in policy, to be reclassified and fired without cause. That opens the door wide to political interference and hiring based on loyalty rather than qualifications or expertise.It also violates the due process rights federal workers currently have. Under current law (5 U.S.C. § 7513), career employees are supposed to be protected from unjust termination—they deserve fair procedures and a valid reason before being removed. Schedule F throws those protections out the window, weakening both job security and the ability of employees to offer honest, expert advice—even when it’s not politically convenient.There’s also the issue of OPM’s responsibility. The Office of Personnel Management is legally required (5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq.) to uphold the merit system principles. Schedule F would force OPM to work against its own mission by placing political pressure on career staff, disrupting the stability and impartiality of federal programs that are meant to last across administrations.Bottom line: Schedule F is a dangerous idea. It threatens good governance, undermines the independence of the civil service, and chips away at the rule of law. I urge the administration and OPM to stand firm against any attempt to revive or implement it.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment: I appreciate the opportunity to comment on the Office of Personnel Management’s proposed rule (Docket OPM-2025-0004; RIN 3206-AO80) to create a new “Schedule Policy/Career” excepted-service category for policy-influencing positions. I strongly oppose the retroactive application of this rule to current incumbents and instead urge OPM to limit any reclassification to positions as they become vacant and to new hires going forward.Career employees have accumulated a property interest in their civil-service status, including pre-removal notice, hearing rights, and MSPB appeals under Chapters 43 and 75 of Title 5, U.S. Code. Stripping these protections en masse violates the Fifth Amendment’s guarantee that no person shall be deprived of “life, liberty, or property, without due process of law,” and the Supreme Court has recognized that significant employment-related entitlements constitute such property interests. Retaining protections for incumbents while applying Schedule Policy/Career only prospectively would honor those settled expectations without undermining accountability goals.Congress narrowly authorized exceptions to civil-service protections for “positions determined to be of a confidential, policy-determining, policy-making, or policy-advocating character”—i.e., political appointees—not career incumbents. Section 7511(b)(2) of Title 5 confirms that exclusions from Chapter 75 attach to the position’s nature, not to who occupies it. OPM’s attempt to remove protections from existing incumbents therefore exceeds its regulatory authority under the Civil Service Reform Act.The Civil Service Reform Act requires that any exception to competitive-service requirements be “necessary” and warranted by “conditions of good administration” (5 U.S.C. § 3302). Retroactively sweeping in current employees en masse cannot satisfy that strict standard, as it neither targets proven instances of serious misconduct nor ensures rigorous, case-by-case determinations by individual agency heads.Under the APA, rescinding or revising existing regulations requires the same notice-and-comment procedures used to promulgate them (5 U.S.C. § 553). Yet the proposed rule attempts to render inoperative the Biden-era regulations via a brief NPRM rather than full, reasoned analysis of thousands of comments and empirical data. This approach risks arbitrary and capricious decision-making prohibited by APA § 706.I respectfully oppose the entire concept of creating a Schedule Policy/Career excepted-service category, the proposed rule itself, and the accompanying Executive Order. Establishing an at-will layer over career positions politicizes roles that Congress intended to remain nonpartisan, undermines merit-system principles, and eliminates foundational due-process safeguards for thousands of federal employees.For these reasons, I urge OPM to withdraw the retroactive reclassification component and the broader Schedule Policy/Career initiative. Civil-service protections should remain intact for current incumbents, with any new accountability measures applied only prospectively to vacated positions and new hires.

comment: To Whom It May Concern,I am writing to express strong opposition to any proposal or policy that would replace nonpartisan civil servants involved in the National Institutes of Health (NIH) grantmaking process with political appointees. title: Comment from Steven Mann
comment: To Whom It May Concern:I strongly oppose the proposed rule that would establish a new Schedule Policy/Career employment category. This rule raises serious legal concerns, including direct conflict with the Civil Service Reform Act of 1978 (CSRA) and well-established constitutional due process protections for federal employees.1. Violation of the Civil Service Reform Act (5 U.S.C. §§ 2301–2302)The CSRA enshrines the merit system principles as the cornerstone of federal employment. Specifically, 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(2) states that "all employees and applicants for employment should receive fair and equitable treatment in all aspects of personnel management… with proper regard for their privacy and constitutional rights."Furthermore, 5 U.S.C. § 7513 mandates that adverse actions, including removals and suspensions, be carried out only "for such cause as will promote the efficiency of the service," and requires advance notice, representation, and an opportunity to respond. The proposed Schedule Policy/Career classification unlawfully circumvents these statutory protections by permitting at-will removal without these required procedures.2. Undermining Constitutional Due Process RightsThe U.S. Supreme Court has recognized in Cleveland Board of Education v. Loudermill, 470 U.S. 532 (1985), that public employees with a property interest in their continued employment are entitled to due process before termination. By designating career civil servants as at-will employees and removing their appeal rights, the rule violates this constitutional guarantee.Even policy-influencing roles do not lose their entitlement to basic procedural protections when filled through competitive, nonpolitical appointments. Attempting to redefine these roles to strip away due process is a de facto repeal of civil service rights without Congressional authorization.3. Exceeds OPM’s Statutory AuthorityThe proposed rule attempts to unilaterally reclassify large swaths of the workforce and redefine fundamental aspects of federal employment. This oversteps the regulatory authority granted to the Office of Personnel Management under 5 U.S.C. § 1103, which does not permit wholesale reclassification of employees to evade the merit-based protections mandated by Congress.Courts have been skeptical of agencies attempting to bypass clear statutory protections through rulemaking. As noted in Util. Air Regulatory Grp. v. EPA, 573 U.S. 302, 324 (2014), "an agency may not rewrite clear statutory terms to suit its own sense of how the statute should operate."4. Risk of Politicization and RetaliationThe proposed rule’s stated justification includes removing employees who “undermine the democratic process by intentionally subverting Presidential directives.” This vague and subjective standard, when combined with at-will status, invites abuse and may be used to purge qualified employees for ideological reasons, not performance—a direct violation of 5 U.S.C. § 2302(b)(10), which prohibits discrimination based on political affiliation.Conclusion:The proposed rule is not only bad policy but also likely unlawful. It threatens to erode the apolitical nature of the civil service, bypasses core legal protections enshrined in the CSRA and the Constitution, and grants the Executive Branch undue power over career personnel.I urge OPM to withdraw this proposal in its entirety.

title: Comment from Benjamin  Peracchio
comment: I am writing to express my strong opposition to the proposed rule (OPM-2025-0004-0001) that would reintroduce a Schedule F-type classification in the federal workforce. This policy is misguided, legally questionable, and threatens the nonpartisan integrity of the civil service.First, the proposal undermines the Civil Service Reform Act of 1978 (5 U.S.C. § 7511), which limits the exception of civil service protections to a narrow category of positions that are “confidential, policy-determining, policy-making, or policy-advocating.” The proposed rule goes far beyond this intent by opening the door to the mass reclassification of career civil servants without sufficient statutory authority.Second, this proposal raises serious constitutional concerns. Federal employees possess a property interest in their continued employment, and reclassifying positions to at-will status without individualized due process may violate the Fifth Amendment’s Due Process Clause. As highlighted in Kloeckner v. Solis, 568 U.S. 41 (2012), federal employees are entitled to meaningful procedural protections and access to redress. Schedule F undermines those principles.Third, this rule would weaken merit system principles enshrined in federal law, including the requirement that hiring and firing decisions be made based on competence and performance, not political loyalty. The nonpartisan, apolitical character of the civil service is a cornerstone of American democracy and public trust.Reinstating Schedule F would politicize career appointments, damage morale, erode institutional expertise, and violate long-standing legal frameworks designed to ensure government accountability and professionalism.I urge OPM to withdraw this proposal in its entirety

title: Comment from Aubrey Grave
comment: I strongly oppose the implementation or revival of the “Schedule F” classification for federal employees. This proposal will not improve performance, accountability or responsiveness. The proposed action threatens the merit-based civil service system that has underpinned a professional, nonpartisan federal workforce for over a century.The creation of Schedule F directly undermines the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883, which was enacted to combat the spoils system and establish a merit-based hiring process for federal employees. By allowing a broad swath of career civil servants—particularly those involved in policy-making or analysis—to be reclassified and potentially terminated without cause, Schedule F opens the door to politically motivated hiring and firing. This is antithetical to the principle of an apolitical civil service enshrined in 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which mandates that federal employment decisions be based on merit and free from political influence.The vague and sweeping criteria for inclusion in Schedule F violate the due process protections guaranteed by 5 U.S.C. § 7513, which requires cause and procedural safeguards for the removal of career federal employees. Stripping thousands of workers of these protections not only weakens accountability but also risks chilling expert advice and dissent within agencies—undermining the very effectiveness of government operations.The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) is also bound by 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq. to support the merit system principles. Implementing Schedule F contradicts this statutory mission and places undue political pressure on career professionals, compromising the integrity and continuity of federal programs across administrations.In conclusion, the Schedule F proposal poses a grave threat to the foundational principles of good governance, civil service independence, and the rule of law. I urge the administration and OPM to reject any regulatory framework that seeks to implement or revive this dangerous classification."

title: Comment from Ian Towers
comment: The Office of Personnel Management’s (OPM) proposed rule, OPM-2025-0004-0001, amending 5 CFR Part 731, delegates authority to the OPM Director to make suitability determinations and issue removal directives for federal employees based on post-appointment conduct. This aligns with the reintroduction of Schedule F, rebranded as Schedule Policy/Career in 2025, aiming to reclassify career employees as at-will, stripping them of merit-based protections. As a union-minded scholar, I oppose this rule for its assault on meritocracy, due process, and labor rights, threatening the integrity of the federal civil service.The federal civil service, rooted in the Pendleton Act of 1883, ensures competence and impartiality, shielding employees from political pressures. The proposed rule undermines this by centralizing authority in the OPM Director, mandating agency compliance within five workdays, and aligning with Schedule F’s agenda to politicize the workforce. Schedule F, introduced in 2020 and revoked in 2021, sought to reclassify employees in policy roles as at-will, enabling dismissals without cause. Its 2025 revival, as noted on X, risks replacing career professionals with loyalists, prioritizing politics over expertise.The rule’s vague criteria for “unsuitable” conduct invite abuse, allowing subjective or politicized removals. This contradicts merit-based principles, where decisions should reflect performance, not loyalty. Centralizing authority bypasses agencies’ contextual knowledge, eroding the decentralized structure that ensures fairness. Historically, suitability determinations balanced agency needs with employee rights; this rule tilts toward arbitrary discipline, undermining trust in governance.Due process, a cornerstone of labor law, is gutted by the rule’s five-day compliance mandate, limiting employees’ ability to challenge decisions via the Merit Systems Protection Board or unions. This disproportionately harms unionized workers, whose collective bargaining agreements protect against unjust actions. The rule’s silence on union involvement signals a deliberate sidelining of labor, chilling federal workers’ ability to engage in union activities or exercise First Amendment rights. Such ambiguity risks targeting employees for non-job-related conduct, fostering fear and compliance over independence.The rule operationalizes Schedule F by enabling rapid dismissals of employees deemed misaligned with political priorities. X posts highlight Schedule F as a “dangerous” politicization of public service, undermining agencies’ impartiality. This institutional capture prioritizes partisan agendas, demoralizing workers and reducing expertise in critical areas like public health or environmental protection. The sociological impact—eroding trust in institutions—threatens democratic governance, as politicized agencies may neglect equitable policymaking.Economically, the rule destabilizes federal workers, many supporting families and communities. At-will employment creates uncertainty, disproportionately affecting marginalized groups vulnerable to discriminatory “suitability” interpretations. Socially, a loyalist-driven civil service may prioritize political goals over public needs, exacerbating inequalities in healthcare, poverty, or environmental justice. This betrays the civil service’s oath to the Constitution, not any administration.The rule’s alignment with Schedule F demands its withdrawal. It threatens the meritocratic foundation of the civil service, erodes labor protections, and risks long-term harm to governance. If OPM proceeds, it must: 1) reaffirm merit-based criteria; 2) ensure robust due process with extended timelines and appeals; 3) consult unions to preserve bargaining rights; 4) reject Schedule F’s politicization; and 5) enhance transparency through public hearings.Federal employees deserve a system that upholds fairness, not one that sacrifices them to political expediency. The civil service’s integrity hinges on rejecting this rule and recommitting to merit, impartiality, and labor rights.Citations•White House, Strengthening the Suitability and Fitness of the Federal Workforce, 2025.

comment: I am firmly opposed to any effort to implement or reinstate the “Schedule F” classification within the federal workforce. This measure would fundamentally erode the merit-based civil service system that has ensured a professional, nonpartisan federal government for over a hundred years.To begin with, Schedule F runs directly counter to the intent of the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883, which was designed to dismantle the spoils system by instituting merit-based hiring for federal roles. Reclassifying large numbers of career civil servants—especially those involved in policy-making or analysis—would expose them to dismissal without cause. This creates a clear path for politically driven employment decisions, contradicting the core tenet of a politically neutral civil service outlined in 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which safeguards employment decisions from partisan influence.Additionally, the broad and ambiguous criteria for placing employees under Schedule F are inconsistent with the due process rights granted under 5 U.S.C. § 7513. That statute requires justified cause and procedural fairness in disciplinary actions involving federal employees. Removing these protections would not only compromise accountability but also stifle open dialogue and expert input within agencies, ultimately weakening the effectiveness of public administration.The Office of Personnel Management (OPM), as governed by 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq., has a duty to uphold the merit system principles. Implementing Schedule F would run contrary to this obligation, introducing undue political interference into a system meant to be impartial and resilient across changing administrations.In summary, Schedule F represents a serious threat to the integrity, independence, and legal foundations of our civil service. I strongly urge both the administration and OPM to reject any regulatory action aimed at bringing this classification back into practice.

title: Comment from Elizabeth Husmann
comment: I’m strongly against bringing back or creating anything like the “Schedule F” classification for federal employees. It’s a serious threat to the merit-based civil service system that’s helped keep our government professional and nonpartisan for over 100 years.Let’s be real—Schedule F basically goes against everything the Pendleton Act of 1883 was designed to fix. That law was put in place to stop the old “spoils system” and make sure federal jobs are awarded based on qualifications, not political connections. But Schedule F would let a huge number of career civil servants—especially folks involved in policy work—get reclassified and possibly fired without any real cause. That opens the door to political loyalty tests, which totally goes against the whole idea of a neutral, professional civil service. Federal law (5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8)) clearly says hiring and firing should be based on merit, not politics.It also raises big red flags when it comes to due process. The rules in 5 U.S.C. § 7513 are there to make sure career employees can’t just be fired on a whim—they’re supposed to have protections and a fair process. Taking that away from thousands of federal workers doesn’t just hurt morale, it could seriously chill open debate and expert input inside agencies. That’s bad news for effective government.The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) is supposed to uphold those merit system values (per 5 U.S.C. § 1101 and beyond), and Schedule F would force them to go in the exact opposite direction. It puts unfair political pressure on career employees and threatens the stability of programs that need to work across different administrations.Bottom line: Schedule F is a major step backwards. It undermines good governance, weakens the independence of civil servants, and chips away at the rule of law. I really hope the administration and OPM will walk away from this idea and not bring it back in any form.

title: Comment from Jacob Garrett
comment: I unequivocally oppose the implementation—or any effort toward the reinstatement—of the “Schedule F” classification within the federal civil service. Such a proposal represents a fundamental threat to the merit-based framework that has sustained a professional and politically neutral federal workforce for well over a century.At its core, Schedule F subverts the principles established by the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883, legislation specifically designed to dismantle the spoils system and replace it with a system grounded in meritocratic hiring and retention. By authorizing the wholesale reclassification of career civil servants—particularly those engaged in policy formulation or analysis—Schedule F effectively enables arbitrary dismissals untethered from cause or performance. This erodes the apolitical nature of the federal workforce, directly contravening the mandates articulated in 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which codify the requirement that federal personnel decisions be guided solely by merit and shielded from partisan interference.Furthermore, the broad and imprecise criteria for Schedule F designation pose significant due process concerns. This undermines the principle of an apolitical civil service, as outlined in 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which requires that federal employment decisions be based on merit and free from political influence. An administration’s efficiency cannot come at the expense of the constitutional commitment to impartial governance.Advocates also claim that Schedule F would improve accountability by removing underperforming employees more easily. Yet the broad and vague criteria for inclusion in Schedule F contradict the due process protections guaranteed by 5 U.S.C. § 7513, which require cause and procedural safeguards for removing career federal employees. Stripping these protections weakens—not strengthens—accountability. It could discourage employees from voicing dissenting opinions or providing candid expert advice, ultimately harming the effectiveness of government operations.Additionally, supporters suggest that implementing Schedule F would streamline federal operations by aligning staff more closely with an administration’s goals. But this short-term alignment would come at the expense of long-term stability and continuity in federal programs. The Office of Personnel Management (OPM), bound by 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq. to uphold merit system principles, would be acting against its statutory mission by implementing Schedule F. The result would be undue political pressure on career professionals, threatening the integrity and effectiveness of federal programs across administrations.In summary, while Schedule F may appear to offer greater flexibility and efficiency to the executive branch, its adoption poses a grave threat to the foundational principles of good governance, civil service independence, and the rule of law. title: Comment from Anonymous
comment: During the 19th Century, federal employment was rife with corruption; employees obtained or retained their jobs based not on merit or competence, but on their political affiliation. The Civil Service Reform Act of 1978 (CSRA) established the current merit-based system in the federal workforce, outlining protections and expectations for a federal employee, while also defining exceptions, such as the historically and realistically miniscule group of political employees. The proposed rule seeks to expand "political appointee" to include career employees, stripping them of the protections they have enjoyed since 1978. I am concerned that this rule will inevitably lead to federal employment populated by people retained exclusively for their loyalty or connections to individuals rather than to the mission of supporting all Americans through the government made by the People and for the People. Furthermore, the CSRA does not extend to the President the power to strip career employees of their protections under CSRA, but only political appointees. For the definition of a political appointee, see 5 U.S.C. § 9803(c)(2)(A) "the term 'political appointee' means an employee who holds a position which has been excepted from the competitive service by reason of its confidential, policy-determining, policy-making, or policy-advocating character", 7 U.S.C § 6992(e)(2)(D) "the term 'political appointee' means an individual occupying a position which has been excepted from the competitive service by reason of its confidential, policy-determining, policy-making, or policy-advocating character" and 38 U.S.C. § 725(c) "The term 'political appointee' means any employee [...] who holds a position which has been excepted from the competitive service by reason of its confidential, policy-determining, policy-making, or policy-advocating character." There is extensive legal precedent, with commentary on the spirit and intent of CSRA from the Supreme Court and Congress itself. Under constitutional and statutory interpretation, ultimately Schedule F is unlawful, if politically convenient. It is my hope that our great Government upholds the rule of law and protects our career civil servants so that federal employment does not become like those seen in adversarial countries, where knowing the right person or currying political favor are the sole keys to success and corruption abounds.

comment: I strongly oppose the implementation or revival of the “Schedule F” classification for federal employees. I urge the administration and OPM to reject any regulatory framework that seeks to implement or revive this dangerous classification.

title: Comment from Joshua Driesman
comment: While I support the goal of enhancing performance and accountability in government, I strongly oppose this rule as written. By creating a new Schedule Policy/Career within the excepted service and exempting those employees from the adverse action procedures and appeals protections under 5 U.S.C. chapters 43 and 75, this proposal fundamentally undermines the nonpartisan merit-based civil service established under the Civil Service Reform Act of 1978 (CSRA).The CSRA was enacted to ensure that employees are “protected against arbitrary action, personal favoritism, or coercion for partisan political purposes” and to uphold an effective and efficient merit-based civil service (5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)). This proposed rule reverses those principles by designating certain career positions as effectively at-will, subject to removal without meaningful procedural safeguards. This would significantly weaken civil service protections that have been in place for decades, diminishing the neutrality and continuity of our federal workforce.Additionally, by shifting a broad class of career positions into an at-will category that can be easily reshaped by each incoming administration, this rule risks triggering cyclical, large-scale turnover every four to eight years. Such turnover would deplete institutional knowledge and discourage long-term public service careers. It would also erode the impartiality that is essential to maintaining public trust in the implementation of laws and policies.Although the proposed rule maintains that these positions will be filled on a nonpartisan basis, the reality is that removing traditional appeal rights and due process protections opens the door to politicized removals and the perception thereof. Even the best-intentioned leaders cannot prevent such perceptions when protections are removed, particularly in politically sensitive policy areas.In conclusion, while the desire to streamline personnel actions is understandable, it must not come at the expense of the core values of a professional, stable, and impartial federal civil service. I respectfully urge OPM to withdraw or substantially revise this proposed rule and instead seek solutions that maintain accountability while preserving the integrity of the merit system as envisioned in the CSRA.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment: The proposed Schedule F classification raises significant legal concerns as it violates multiple federal statutes and constitutional protections designed to uphold a nonpartisan, merit-based civil service. Below is the detailed analysis of the legal issues associated with Schedule F:1. Violation of the Civil Service Reform Act of 1978 (CSRA)The CSRA establishes a merit-based system for federal employment, providing protections against arbitrary dismissal. Schedule F seeks to reclassify certain policy-influencing positions, effectively removing these protections and allowing for at-will termination. Reclassification undermines the CSRA’s intent and structure. Notably, the CSRA permits exceptions for positions of a “confidential or policy-determining character,” but Schedule F’s broad application exceeds this narrow scope. The Roth v. Brownell decision reinforces that reclassification cannot strip employees of their CSRA protections without due process. 2. Contravention of the Lloyd–La Follette Act of 1912This Act mandates that federal employees cannot be removed without notice and a written explanation. By converting positions to Schedule F, employees lose these procedural safeguards, conflicting with the Act’s requirements. The Roth case further supports that reclassification does not nullify these protections.3. Potential Violation of the Due Process Clause of the Fifth AmendmentFederal employees have a property interest in their continued employment, protected under the Fifth Amendment. The Supreme Court’s decision in Cleveland Board of Education v. Loudermill affirms that due process is required before terminating such employment. Schedule F’s provision for at-will dismissal without prior notice or hearing raises constitutional concerns.4. Breach of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA)The APA requires that significant regulatory changes undergo a notice-and-comment period and that agencies provide a reasoned explanation for such changes. The implementation of Schedule F lacks sufficient justification and fails to adhere to APA procedures.5. Undermining the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883The Pendleton Act established the principle of merit-based hiring and protection from political influence. Schedule F’s reclassification could reintroduce a patronage system, allowing for the dismissal of employees based on political considerations, contrary to the Act’s objectives.6. Erosion of Whistleblower ProtectionsWhistleblower statutes protect federal employees who report misconduct. By removing civil service protections through Schedule F, employees may be deterred from reporting wrongdoing due to fear of retaliation, thereby weakening these legal safeguards.7. Application of the Major Questions DoctrineThe Major Questions Doctrine holds that significant policy changes require clear congressional authorization. Given the substantial impact of Schedule F on federal employment, its implementation without explicit legislative approval is considered unlawful under this doctrine.ConclusionThe proposed Schedule F classification poses several legal challenges by violating established federal laws and constitutional protections. Its implementation could fundamentally alter the structure and integrity of the federal civil service, leading to increased politicization and diminished employee rights.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment: "I strongly oppose the implementation or revival of the “Schedule F” classification for federal employees. This proposal threatens the merit-based civil service system that has underpinned a professional, nonpartisan federal workforce for over a century.First and foremost, the creation of Schedule F directly undermines the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883, which was enacted to combat the spoils system and establish a merit-based hiring process for federal employees. By allowing a broad swath of career civil servants—particularly those involved in policy-making or analysis—to be reclassified and potentially terminated without cause, Schedule F opens the door to politically motivated hiring and firing. This is antithetical to the principle of an apolitical civil service enshrined in 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which mandates that federal employment decisions be based on merit and free from political influence.Moreover, the vague and sweeping criteria for inclusion in Schedule F violate the due process protections guaranteed by 5 U.S.C. § 7513, which requires cause and procedural safeguards for the removal of career federal employees. Stripping thousands of workers of these protections not only weakens accountability but also risks chilling expert advice and dissent within agencies—undermining the very effectiveness of government operations.The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) is also bound by 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq. to support the merit system principles. Implementing Schedule F contradicts this statutory mission and places undue political pressure on career professionals, compromising the integrity and continuity of federal programs across administrations.In conclusion, the Schedule F proposal poses a grave threat to the foundational principles of good governance, civil service independence, and the rule of law. I urge the administration and OPM to reject any regulatory framework that seeks to implement or revive this dangerous classification."

It’s a smart, stabilizing policy for our turbulent political era and for the future of our democracy.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment: Public Comment on OPM-2025-0004-0001Subject: Official Comment From the Department of No Seriously This Is RealDear OPM,I am writing today not as a government employee, but as a humble observer of organizational chaos, a fan of functional bridges, and someone who believes it’s mildly important that the person reviewing our nation’s financial system knows what a spreadsheet is.This Schedule Policy Career proposal is, with all due respect, the most elegantly ridiculous idea I’ve seen since someone decided to rank hurricanes based on vibes. It’s beautifully inefficient, gloriously shortsighted, and so unburdened by historical memory it could win a gold medal in the Amnesia Olympics.Let’s take a quick tour of the world this rule creates.Imagine waking up and learning your child’s science teacher has been replaced by Dave, who once read a cereal box that mentioned climate. Dave doesn’t “do degrees,” but he feels strongly that gravity is a liberal hoax.At the DMV, the clerk tells you they no longer issue licenses based on testing. Now it’s just a handshake and a loyalty oath. Eye exams are considered elitist.At the Federal Aviation Administration, pilot certifications have been replaced with personality quizzes. As long as you “believe you can fly,” you’re good to go.Meanwhile, your food inspector is now a lifestyle coach who once did a juice cleanse and described mayo as “naturally shelf-stable.” The bank examiner is a guy who shouts “vibe check” before approving mergers. And the cybersecurity lead has logged into Gmail exactly once and called it “pretty straightforward.”These are not jokes. These are logical extensions of what happens when you decide that anyone who might influence policy should serve at the pleasure of politics, not the public.You say it’s about flexibility. But we already have flexibility. It’s called “rules that work.” We already have accountability. It’s called “managers.” What we don’t need is a system where someone can be fired for doing their job too well—specifically, if their job involves saying, “I read the law and… you can’t do that.”We spent over a century building a professional, nonpartisan civil service to keep the gears turning when elected officials change. We built firewalls between facts and feelings. This proposal takes a sledgehammer to those firewalls and replaces them with polite nodding.If this rule passes, we won’t have a federal workforce. We’ll have a talent show. And the only judging criteria will be, “Did you clap hard enough during the last briefing?”I oppose this rule not as a partisan. Not as a bureaucrat. But as someone who occasionally drinks water, crosses bridges, pays taxes, and hopes the person overseeing critical national infrastructure isn’t chosen based on whether they forwarded the right meme in 2023.Please don’t do this. We like our food safe, our data encrypted, and our facts intact.Sincerely,A taxpayer with a working memory and low tolerance for nonsenseOffice of Oh Come On You Have to Be Kidding MeSchedule PC-911, Clearance Level: Basic Decency

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment: This proposed rule is just the latest in a series of calculated moves by the 47th administration to amass - and inevitably abuse - unearned political power. Federal employees, by and large, are mission-driven. They are motivated primarily by a desire to do good work that will benefit the American people, despite knowing those who will benefit most will likely never know, understand, or appreciate the work they do. title: Comment from Anonymous
comment: Subject: Public Comment Opposing OPM Proposed Rule 2025-004I write to express deep concern regarding OPM’s proposed rule (OPM-2025-004), which purports to enhance accountability within the civil service by creating a new employment category for certain policy-influencing roles. While accountability is an important goal, this rule risks politicizing the civil service and weakening the foundations of impartial governance that have served our democracy for over a century.1. Threat to Civil Service Neutrality:The rule creates ambiguity around what constitutes a “policy-influencing” position, and opens the door to discretionary and potentially politically motivated removals. This fundamentally undermines the principle of a nonpartisan civil service. Career federal employees must be able to offer honest, evidence-based guidance to leadership—regardless of political climate—without fear of reprisal.2. Chilling Effect on Public Servants:The prospect of being removed for subjective or ideologically driven reasons may deter federal employees from providing critical but politically inconvenient information. This chilling effect degrades policy-making and weakens government oversight functions.3. Risk to Institutional Knowledge and Continuity:Federal employees in policy-advisory roles often possess years—sometimes decades—of institutional knowledge. Sweeping removals in these roles threaten the long-term effectiveness of agencies, especially in complex fields like national security, public health, and regulatory enforcement.4. Erosion of Public Trust:The public depends on a professional and apolitical federal workforce. Perceptions of increased political interference in the civil service will diminish public confidence in government decisions, enforcement actions, and policy execution.5. Disincentive for Talent Recruitment and Retention:This rule may deter talented individuals from pursuing public service, knowing their careers could hinge not on performance or ethics, but on political alignment. That is antithetical to the merit-based ideals OPM is charged with upholding.In summary, while efforts to improve government performance are commendable, this rule appears to prioritize political loyalty over professional excellence and nonpartisan service. I urge OPM to withdraw or substantially revise this rule to ensure it aligns with the foundational values of merit, neutrality, and long-term institutional resilience.

title: Comment from Joan Jefferies
comment: I am firmly opposed to any effort to create or revive the “Schedule F” classification for federal employees.  This proposal would strike at the heart of the merit‐based civil service system that has ensured a professional, nonpartisan federal workforce since the Pendleton Act was passed in 1883.Under that landmark reform, hiring and promotion in the federal government became tied to objective measures of competence rather than political allegiance.  By designating large swaths of policy analysts, program managers, inspectors and other career staff as “Schedule F,” the administration could strip them of long-standing due-process protections, reclassify them at will, and terminate them without cause—effectively reinstating the very spoils-system abuses that Pendleton and the Civil Service Reform Act of 1978 (CSRA) were meant to abolish.  Such a move would conflict directly with 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which requires that federal employment decisions rest solely on merit and be insulated from partisan pressure.Moreover, resurrecting Schedule F would undermine institutional knowledge and discourage top-flight professionals from entering or remaining in public service.  It would chill candid analysis and weaken agencies’ ability to offer neutral, data-driven advice, ultimately eroding public trust in government.  In 2020, an executive order first established Schedule F; it was revoked the following year in recognition of these risks.  Reviving it now would not only reverse that sound judgment but also set a dangerous precedent for politicized personnel management in every corner of the federal establishment.

comment: I am writing to comment on proposed rule OPM 2025-0004 "Improving Performance, Accountability and Responsiveness in the Civil Service".This proposed rule does not clearly identify the scope of Federal employees that would be impacted. Once the subject policy-making roles are identified, I recommend completing an impact assessment. These should be publicly considered when proposing this dramatic change to the makeup of the civil service. title: Comment from Anonymous
comment: A bedrock principle of our republic is a professional and nonpartisan civil service, a system carefully constructed on merit since the passage of the Pendleton Act in 1883. The proposed "Schedule F" classification poses a significant threat to this enduring foundation. By potentially allowing the reclassification and dismissal without cause of a broad spectrum of career civil servants, particularly those engaged in crucial policy formulation and analysis, this initiative opens a dangerous pathway for political considerations to unduly influence hiring and firing decisions. This directly contravenes the spirit and letter of 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which clearly mandates that federal employment decisions must be rooted in merit-based principles, shielded from the vagaries of political influence.Furthermore, the imprecise and expansive criteria for inclusion under "Schedule F" raise serious concerns regarding the fundamental due process protections currently afforded to career federal employees under 5 U.S.C. § 7513. These established safeguards require just cause and adherence to procedural fairness before the removal of dedicated public servants. To strip potentially thousands of these individuals of such essential protections not only weakens the mechanisms of accountability within our government but also creates a chilling effect on the willingness of experts to offer candid advice and dissenting opinions, ultimately undermining the operational effectiveness of our governmental institutions.The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) also bears a statutory responsibility, as outlined in 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq., to vigorously support and uphold the principles of the merit system. The implementation of "Schedule F" stands in direct contradiction to this vital statutory mission. It would subject career professionals to undue political pressures, thereby compromising the integrity and the essential continuity of federal programs that serve the American people across different administrations.In conclusion, the "Schedule F" proposal represents a grave danger to the fundamental tenets of sound governance, the cherished independence of our civil service, and the overarching rule of law. It is my considered and firm conviction that the current administration and the Office of Personnel Management must resolutely reject any regulatory framework that seeks to implement or revive this ill-conceived and potentially damaging classification.

Federal employees' loyalty is where it should be - to the Constitution, the rule of law, and the public they serve. The career employees need to be protected from the winds of political change, so their hard-won experience and expertise can continue to serve the country as a whole.

title: Comment from L Dickens
comment: The Competitive Service Reform Act established a merit-based system that was free from political interference. This system ensures that the American public is served by its government by employing the best and brightest rather than those most loyal to a specific political party or figure. The proposed rule undoes these protections. It is also overly broad by including every person who could conceivably be considered as influencing policy. Any scientist, program officer, communications manager, or other professional could be lumped into that category as all play a role in generating evidence for policy or carrying it out. How will these individuals be identified? Will their position description simply be searched for the word “policy?”

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment: The proposed rule changes are completely misguided. In order to have an accountable and responsive civil service, civil service employees need to have the assurance that they will not lose their job at the whim of a supervisor. Employees working/living under the perceived threat of losing their jobs at any moment for any reason will inherently be distracted from completing their work efficiently. If an employee is not doing their job effectively, it is the managements responsibility to document any insufficiencies, provide warnings and opportunities for the employee to improve. Termination of employee should require documented proof that they are not doing their job. Management should not be able to terminate an employee because they do not like an individual for any reason, specifically for race, gender, age, ethnicity, or political views. The proposed rule change would allow such abuses to occur. In addition, civil service employees involved in grantmaking decisions should not be considered policymakers. Their job is to listen to the communities in need and assess in good faith what are the most pressing needs (i.e. drafting funding opportunity announcements), evaluating the grants without bias, and recommending grant recipients without bias. This process should be driven by needs not policy. The proposed rule changes would allow current civil service employees to be replaced with policymakers. Policymakers making these decisions leads to sycophants and corruption. Decisions will no longer be made in the best interest of the communities, but in the best interest of the administration. No matter your political swaying, the proposed rule changes are bad for the country and should not be implemented.

title: Comment from William Krahe
comment: This partisan rule would result in a regrettable return to the spoils system and decimate the institutional knowledge critical to maintaining a functioning government that serves the American people.I strongly oppose the implementation or revival of the “Schedule F” classification for federal employees. This proposal threatens the merit-based civil service system that has underpinned a professional, nonpartisan federal workforce for over a century.First and foremost, the creation of Schedule F directly undermines the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act of 1883, which was enacted to combat the spoils system and establish a merit-based hiring process for federal employees. By allowing a broad swath of career civil servants—particularly those involved in policy-making or analysis—to be reclassified and potentially terminated without cause, Schedule F opens the door to politically motivated hiring and firing. This is antithetical to the principle of an apolitical civil service enshrined in 5 U.S.C. § 2301(b)(8), which mandates that federal employment decisions be based on merit and free from political influence.Moreover, the vague and sweeping criteria for inclusion in Schedule F violate the due process protections guaranteed by 5 U.S.C. § 7513, which requires cause and procedural safeguards for the removal of career federal employees. Stripping thousands of workers of these protections not only weakens accountability but also risks chilling expert advice and dissent within agencies—undermining the very effectiveness of government operations.The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) is also bound by 5 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq. to support the merit system principles. Implementing Schedule F contradicts this statutory mission and places undue political pressure on career professionals, compromising the integrity and continuity of federal programs across administrations.In conclusion, the Schedule F proposal poses a grave threat to the foundational principles of good governance, civil service independence, and the rule of law. I urge the administration and OPM to reject any regulatory framework that seeks to implement or revive this dangerous classification.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment: I am writing to express my strongest opposition to the Office of Personnel Management's proposed rule implementing Executive Order 14171, which would create a new "Schedule Policy/Career" in the excepted service and remove procedural protections and appeal rights for employees designated as occupying "policy-influencing" positions.This proposed rule would significantly disrupt the functioning and effectiveness of the federal government in several critical ways:1.Compromising the Merit System and Operational Continuity: The proposed changes undermine foundational merit principles while threatening the professional, non-partisan civil service that ensures continuity across administrations. Career civil servants with institutional knowledge are essential for maintaining operations during transitions of power.2.Creating Workforce Instability and Loss of Expertise: At-will employment for "policy-influencing" positions would lead to increased turnover and loss of specialized knowledge. This destabilization would make it difficult to recruit and retain talented professionals essential to government operations.3.Undermining Due Process and Employee Morale: Eliminating MSPB appeal rights removes crucial protections that ensure merit-based employment decisions. This change would significantly damage morale across agencies, as employees face uncertainty about reclassification of their positions.4.Expanding Political Influence Through Vague Criteria: The term "policy-influencing" is inherently broad and subject to interpretation. Without clear criteria, this designation could be applied to numerous career positions, extending far beyond roles that genuinely involve policy formulation, leading to increased politicization of government operations.5.Inhibiting Expert Advice and Professional Judgment: Federal employees must provide candid professional advice without fear of summary dismissal. This rule would discourage career employees from offering their best professional judgment when it might contradict political preferences, undermining evidence-based decision-making across government.While I recognize the importance of addressing performance management challenges in the federal workforce, this approach creates far more problems than it solves. I urge OPM to withdraw this proposed rule and instead work with stakeholders to develop alternative approaches that strengthen accountability while preserving the integrity of the merit-based civil service system.

Allowing broad reclassification of positions undermines these principles, potentially leading to appointments based on political affiliation rather than qualifications.​Threat to Nonpartisan Expertise: Federal employees provide critical, nonpartisan expertise essential for informed policymaking. I urge OPM to reconsider this proposed rule and uphold the protections that ensure a fair and competent federal workforce.Thank you for considering my comments.

title: Comment from Anonymous
comment: Subject: Opposition to OPM-2025-0004-0001 – Protect Civil Service Independence from Political Loyalty TestsI write in strong opposition to the proposed rule OPM-2025-0004-0001, which would open the door to reintroducing mechanisms similar to those under former Executive Order 13957. This rule risks politicizing the federal workforce by allowing the reclassification of career civil servants into a category of employees who can be hired and fired without the usual merit-based protections.At the heart of my concern is the threat this proposal poses to the independence and integrity of the civil service. If enacted, the rule would enable the executive branch to subject career officials to implicit or explicit loyalty tests, requiring alignment with the political priorities of the President rather than adherence to law, science, and the public interest.Key Issues:Encouraging Loyalty over Expertise:The reclassification of positions removes critical due process protections, effectively allowing political appointees to dismiss civil servants based on perceived loyalty rather than competence or adherence to ethical obligations. This creates a chilling effect where employees may feel pressured to conform politically to avoid retaliation or termination.Undermining Nonpartisan Governance:Civil servants are obligated to serve the public and uphold the Constitution—not to serve the personal or political interests of any one administration. Weakening their independence by tying job security to political loyalty erodes the public’s trust in an impartial government.Historical Precedent and Rejection:A similar framework was widely criticized and ultimately revoked in the past because it posed such an obvious risk to democratic norms and accountable governance. Reintroducing this idea—especially after its rejection—threatens to normalize a dangerous precedent.Stability and Continuity in Government:Our nation depends on a stable, professional civil service that can endure across administrations. Allowing widespread reclassification risks turning expert agencies into echo chambers, reducing their ability to provide honest, evidence-based policy guidance.Conclusion:This proposed rule is not about reform—it is about control. We must not allow a return to a system where public servants are forced to pass political loyalty tests to keep their jobs. I urge OPM to preserve the integrity of the civil service by withdrawing this proposal and upholding the principles of impartial, merit-based government employment.Thank you for the opportunity to comment.
